sentences.text: This paper deals with the problem of generating the fundamental frequency -LRB- F0 -RRB- contour of speech from a text input for text-to-speech synthesis .
We have previously introduced a statistical model describing the generating process of speech F0 contours , based on the discrete-time version of the Fujisaki model .

One remarkable feature of this model is that it has allowed us to derive an efficient algorithm based on powerful statistical methods for estimating the Fujisaki-model parameters from raw F0 contours .
To associate a sequence of the Fujisaki-model parameters with a text input based on statistical learning , this paper proposes extending this model to a context-dependent one .
We further propose a parameter training algorithm for the present model based on a decision tree-based context clustering .

It deals with the problem of generating the fundamental frequency contour of speech, specifically from text input for text-to-speech synthesis. To address this challenge, the paper proposes extending a statistical model, which is based on the discrete-time version of the Fujisaki model. This model is further enhanced by incorporating a context-dependent approach, which improves the association of model parameters with text inputs. The generating process of speech F0 contours is characterized by its relation to raw F0 contours and encompasses broader terms such as speech F0 contours and F0 contours. Additionally, the present model is based on decision tree-based context clustering, which aids in the effective training of the statistical model for generating natural-sounding speech.

The fundamental frequency (F0) contour of speech is a crucial aspect of text-to-speech synthesis, which involves the challenge of generating a natural pitch variation from text input. This problem encompasses the fundamental frequency itself and is closely related to the broader field of text-to-speech synthesis. The Fujisaki model serves as a theoretical framework for this process, with its parameters being estimated from raw F0 contours, which are the unprocessed data representing the pitch variations in speech. An efficient algorithm, derived from a statistical model, is employed to optimize these parameters, utilizing powerful statistical methods. This paper proposes a parameter training algorithm specifically designed for the present model, which extends the Fujisaki model to enhance the generation of speech F0 contours. Overall, the generating process of speech F0 contours is integral to achieving effective text-to-speech synthesis.
